trans-unit.source: Understand differences between Resource Manager and classic deployment models
trans-unit.target: Understand differences between Resource Manager and classic deployment models

trans-unit.source: Describes the differences between the Resource Manager deployment model and the classic (or Service Management) deployment model.
trans-unit.target: Describes the differences between the Resource Manager deployment model and the classic (or Service Management) deployment model.

trans-unit.source: The Resource Manager deployment model provides a new way to deploy and manage the services that make up your application.
trans-unit.target: The Resource Manager deployment model provides a new way to deploy and manage the services that make up your application.

trans-unit.source: This new model contains important differences from the classic deployment model, and the two models are not completely compatible with each other.
trans-unit.target: This new model contains important differences from the classic deployment model, and the two models are not completely compatible with each other.

trans-unit.source: To simplify the deployment and management of resources, Microsoft recommends that you use Resource Manager for new resources, and, if possible, re-deploy existing resources through Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: To simplify the deployment and management of resources, Microsoft recommends that you use Resource Manager for new resources, and, if possible, re-deploy existing resources through Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: You may also know the classic deployment model as the Service Management model.
trans-unit.target: You may also know the classic deployment model as the Service Management model.

trans-unit.source: This topic describes the differences between the two models, and some of the issues you may encounter when transitioning from the classic model to Resource Manager. It provides an overview of the models but does not cover in detail the differences in individual services. For more details about transitioning Compute, Storage, and Networking resources, see <linkText>Azure Compute, Network & Storage Providers under the Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This topic describes the differences between the two models, and some of the issues you may encounter when transitioning from the classic model to Resource Manager. It provides an overview of the models but does not cover in detail the differences in individual services. For more details about transitioning Compute, Storage, and Networking resources, see <linkText>Azure Compute, Network & Storage Providers under the Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Many resources operate without issue in both the classic model and Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Many resources operate without issue in both the classic model and Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: These resources fully support Resource Manager even if created in the classic model.
trans-unit.target: These resources fully support Resource Manager even if created in the classic model.

trans-unit.source: You can transition to Resource Manager without any concerns or extra effort.
trans-unit.target: You can transition to Resource Manager without any concerns or extra effort.

trans-unit.source: However, a few resource providers offer two versions of the resource (one for classic, and one for Resource Manager) because of the architectural differences between the models.
trans-unit.target: However, a few resource providers offer two versions of the resource (one for classic, and one for Resource Manager) because of the architectural differences between the models.

trans-unit.source: The resource providers that differentiate between the two models are:
trans-unit.target: The resource providers that differentiate between the two models are:

trans-unit.source: Compute
trans-unit.target: Compute

trans-unit.source: Storage
trans-unit.target: Storage

trans-unit.source: Network
trans-unit.target: Network

trans-unit.source: For these resource types, you must be aware of which version you are using because the supported operations will differ.
trans-unit.target: For these resource types, you must be aware of which version you are using because the supported operations will differ.

trans-unit.source: To understand the architectural differences between the two models, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Architecture</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To understand the architectural differences between the two models, see <linkText>Azure Resource Manager Architecture</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Resources created through Resource Manager share the following characteristics:
trans-unit.target: Resources created through Resource Manager share the following characteristics:

trans-unit.source: Created through one of the following methods:
trans-unit.target: Created through one of the following methods:

trans-unit.source: The <linkText>preview portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The <linkText>preview portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>preview portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>preview portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: For Compute, Storage, and Networking resources, you have the option of using either Resourece Manager or Classic deployment.
trans-unit.target: For Compute, Storage, and Networking resources, you have the option of using either Resourece Manager or Classic deployment.

trans-unit.source: Select Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Select Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Resource Manager deployment</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Resource Manager deployment</linkText>

trans-unit.source: PowerShell commands run in the AzureResourceManager mode.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell commands run in the AzureResourceManager mode.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure Resource Manager REST API</linkText><title></title> for REST operations.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure Resource Manager REST API</linkText><title></title> for REST operations.

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI commands run in the arm mode.
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI commands run in the arm mode.

trans-unit.source: The resource type does not include (classic) in the name.
trans-unit.target: The resource type does not include (classic) in the name.

trans-unit.source: The image below shows the type as Storage account.
trans-unit.target: The image below shows the type as Storage account.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>web app</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>web app</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Resources created in the classic deployment model share the following characteristics:
trans-unit.target: Resources created in the classic deployment model share the following characteristics:

trans-unit.source: Created through one of the following methods:
trans-unit.target: Created through one of the following methods:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure portal</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Azure portal</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Azure portal</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Or, the preview portal and you specify Classic deployment (for Compute, Storage, and Networking).
trans-unit.target: Or, the preview portal and you specify Classic deployment (for Compute, Storage, and Networking).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Classic deployment</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Classic deployment</linkText>

trans-unit.source: PowerShell commands run in the AzureServiceManagement mode (which is the default mode, so if do not you specifically switch to AzureResourceManager, you are running in AzureServiceManagement mode).
trans-unit.target: PowerShell commands run in the AzureServiceManagement mode (which is the default mode, so if do not you specifically switch to AzureResourceManager, you are running in AzureServiceManagement mode).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Service Management REST API</linkText><title></title> for REST operations.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Service Management REST API</linkText><title></title> for REST operations.

trans-unit.source: Azure CLI commands run in asm or default mode.
trans-unit.target: Azure CLI commands run in asm or default mode.

trans-unit.source: The resource type includes (classic) in the name.
trans-unit.target: The resource type includes (classic) in the name.

trans-unit.source: The image below shows the type as Storage account (classic).
trans-unit.target: The image below shows the type as Storage account (classic).

trans-unit.source: <linkText>classic type</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>classic type</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can still use the preview portal to manage resources that were created through classic deployment.
trans-unit.target: You can still use the preview portal to manage resources that were created through classic deployment.

trans-unit.source: Resource Manager added the concept of the resource group.
trans-unit.target: Resource Manager added the concept of the resource group.

trans-unit.source: Every resource you create through Resource Manager exists within a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Every resource you create through Resource Manager exists within a resource group.

trans-unit.source: The Resource Manager deployment model provide several benefits:
trans-unit.target: The Resource Manager deployment model provide several benefits:

trans-unit.source: You can deploy, manage, and monitor all of the services for your solution as a group, rather than handling these services individually.
trans-unit.target: You can deploy, manage, and monitor all of the services for your solution as a group, rather than handling these services individually.

trans-unit.source: You can repeatedly deploy your application throughout the app lifecycle and have confidence your resources are deployed in a consistent state.
trans-unit.target: You can repeatedly deploy your application throughout the app lifecycle and have confidence your resources are deployed in a consistent state.

trans-unit.source: You can use declarative templates to define your deployment.
trans-unit.target: You can use declarative templates to define your deployment.

trans-unit.source: You can define the dependencies between resources so they are deployed in the correct order.
trans-unit.target: You can define the dependencies between resources so they are deployed in the correct order.

trans-unit.source: You can apply access control to all services in your resource group because Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) is natively integrated into the management platform.
trans-unit.target: You can apply access control to all services in your resource group because Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) is natively integrated into the management platform.

trans-unit.source: You can apply tags to resources to logically organize all of the resources in your subscription.
trans-unit.target: You can apply tags to resources to logically organize all of the resources in your subscription.

trans-unit.source: Prior to Resource Manager, every resource you created through classic deployment did not exist within a resource group.
trans-unit.target: Prior to Resource Manager, every resource you created through classic deployment did not exist within a resource group.

trans-unit.source: When Resource Manager was added, all resources were retroactively added to default resource groups.
trans-unit.target: When Resource Manager was added, all resources were retroactively added to default resource groups.

trans-unit.source: If you create a resource through classic deployment now, the resource is automatically created within an empty resource group even though you did not specify that resource group at deployment.
trans-unit.target: If you create a resource through classic deployment now, the resource is automatically created within an empty resource group even though you did not specify that resource group at deployment.

trans-unit.source: However, just existing within a resource group does not mean that the resource has been converted to the Resourece Manager model.
trans-unit.target: However, just existing within a resource group does not mean that the resource has been converted to the Resourece Manager model.

trans-unit.source: If the resource was created through classic deployment, you must continue to operate on it through classic operations.
trans-unit.target: If the resource was created through classic deployment, you must continue to operate on it through classic operations.

trans-unit.source: You can move resources to a different resource group, and add new resources to an existing resource group.
trans-unit.target: You can move resources to a different resource group, and add new resources to an existing resource group.

trans-unit.source: So, your resource group can contain a mix of resources created through Resource Manager and classic deployment.
trans-unit.target: So, your resource group can contain a mix of resources created through Resource Manager and classic deployment.

trans-unit.source: This combination of resources can create unexpected results because the resources do not support the same operations.
trans-unit.target: This combination of resources can create unexpected results because the resources do not support the same operations.

trans-unit.source: By using declarative templates, you might be able to simplify your scripts for deployment.
trans-unit.target: By using declarative templates, you might be able to simplify your scripts for deployment.

trans-unit.source: Instead of attempting to convert existing scripts from Service Management to Resource Manager, consider re-working your deployment strategy to take advantage of defining your infrastructure and configuration in the template.
trans-unit.target: Instead of attempting to convert existing scripts from Service Management to Resource Manager, consider re-working your deployment strategy to take advantage of defining your infrastructure and configuration in the template.

trans-unit.source: Tags enable you to logically organize your resources.
trans-unit.target: Tags enable you to logically organize your resources.

trans-unit.source: Only resources created through Resource Manager support tags.
trans-unit.target: Only resources created through Resource Manager support tags.

trans-unit.source: You cannot apply tags to classic resources.
trans-unit.target: You cannot apply tags to classic resources.

trans-unit.source: For more information about using tags in Resource Manager, see <linkText>Using tags to organize your Azure resources</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about using tags in Resource Manager, see <linkText>Using tags to organize your Azure resources</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The resources you created in the classic deployment model do not support Resource Manager operations.
trans-unit.target: The resources you created in the classic deployment model do not support Resource Manager operations.

trans-unit.source: In some cases, a Resource Manager command can retrieve information about a resource created through classic deployment, or can perform an administrative tasks such as moving a classic resource to another resource group, but these cases should not give the impression that the type supports Resource Manager operations.
trans-unit.target: In some cases, a Resource Manager command can retrieve information about a resource created through classic deployment, or can perform an administrative tasks such as moving a classic resource to another resource group, but these cases should not give the impression that the type supports Resource Manager operations.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose you have a resource group that contains Virtual Machines that were created with Resource Manager and classic.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose you have a resource group that contains Virtual Machines that were created with Resource Manager and classic.

trans-unit.source: If you run the following PowerShell command, you will see all of the Virtual Machines:
trans-unit.target: If you run the following PowerShell command, you will see all of the Virtual Machines:

trans-unit.source: However, if you run the Get-AzureVM command, you will only get Virtual Machines that were created with Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: However, if you run the Get-AzureVM command, you will only get Virtual Machines that were created with Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: In general, you should not expect resources created through classic deployment to work with Resource Manager commands.
trans-unit.target: In general, you should not expect resources created through classic deployment to work with Resource Manager commands.

trans-unit.source: When working with resources created through Resource Manager, you should use Resource Manager operations and not switch back to Service Management operations.
trans-unit.target: When working with resources created through Resource Manager, you should use Resource Manager operations and not switch back to Service Management operations.

trans-unit.source: There are some important considerations when working Virtual Machines.
trans-unit.target: There are some important considerations when working Virtual Machines.

trans-unit.source: Virtual machines deployed with the classic deployment model cannot be included in a virtual network deployed with Resource Manager.
trans-unit.target: Virtual machines deployed with the classic deployment model cannot be included in a virtual network deployed with Resource Manager.

trans-unit.source: Virtual machines deployed with the Resource Manager deployment model must be included in a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Virtual machines deployed with the Resource Manager deployment model must be included in a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Virtual machines deployed with the classic deployment model don't have to be included in a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Virtual machines deployed with the classic deployment model don't have to be included in a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: For a list of equivalent Azure CLI commands when transitioning from classic deployment to Resource Manager, see <linkText>Equivalent Resource Manager and Service Management commands for VM operations</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a list of equivalent Azure CLI commands when transitioning from classic deployment to Resource Manager, see <linkText>Equivalent Resource Manager and Service Management commands for VM operations</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For more details about transitioning Compute, Storage, and Networking resources, see <linkText>Azure Compute, Network & Storage Providers under the Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more details about transitioning Compute, Storage, and Networking resources, see <linkText>Azure Compute, Network & Storage Providers under the Azure Resource Manager</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To learn about connecting virtual networks from different deployment models, see <linkText>Connecting classic VNets to new VNets</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn about connecting virtual networks from different deployment models, see <linkText>Connecting classic VNets to new VNets</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To learn about creating declarative deployment templates, see <linkText>Authoring Azure Resource Manager templates</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn about creating declarative deployment templates, see <linkText>Authoring Azure Resource Manager templates</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To see the commands for deploying a template, see <linkText>Deploy an application with Azure Resource Manager template</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To see the commands for deploying a template, see <linkText>Deploy an application with Azure Resource Manager template</linkText><title></title>.
